Application_Facts: Discrepancies in applicant's statements raised concerns about candour; ancillary factors such as funding sources and family details informed the decision.
Misrepresentation_Element: Perceived lack of candour, incomplete background information
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of procedural unfairness; no breach found as applicant was aware of the issues
Evidence_Used: Applicant's statements, funding sources, family details
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility assessment due to lack of candour
Outcome: Judicial review application dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness for factual assessments, correctness for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Decision was reasonable; no breach of procedural fairness occurred

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 183 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Sodhi overstayed his visa, left Canada, and reapplied for a student visa; evidence showed attendance at Algonquin College after departure date.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – decision based on non-compliance, not false information
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness in refusal
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of studies in India during gap period
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned credibility due to academic attendance in Canada post-departure
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Certification of general importance and quashing of refusal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer’s decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded re-entry without authorization based on applicant-provided evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Re-entering Canada without authorization under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Sodhi re-entered Canada illegally after deportation
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Transcripts and diploma indicated Canadian study post-2005 without valid status
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate lawful entry and compliance
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of documentation supporting studies in India or lawful re-entry
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicants must prove they entered Canada legally and will comply with visa terms
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in factual findings and procedural unfairness
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA sections related to admissibility and visa issuance
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Visa officer relied on applicant-submitted documents
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (transcripts, diploma)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA Section 11(1), Section 40(1)

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA Section 40(1)(a) – misrepresentation
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Sodhi did not provide evidence of lawful status or explain presence in Canada after departure
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Deported individual reapplying for student visa
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: History of non-compliance with immigration status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Implied omission of whereabouts and re-entry details
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation that officer failed to give chance to respond to adverse inference
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Student transcripts, diploma, absence of Indian study records
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No documentation proving legal stay outside Canada or authorized re-entry
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's explanation insufficient
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Visa refused due to credibility and compliance concerns
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of administrative decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: All evidence was provided by applicant; no procedural unfairness found

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide consistent information during visa application process
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: paragraph 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Outcome: dismissed
Grounds_for_Claim: inconsistencies in testimonies regarding residence and schooling
Credibility: lack of credibility due to inconsistent information

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Legal_Issue: reasonableness of misrepresentation finding, procedural fairness
Outcome: dismissed
Assessment_Standard: reasonableness standard for Visa Officer's decision
Legal_Standard: standard of review: reasonableness; procedural fairness reviewed on correctness
Application_Factor: cultural factors acknowledged but not excusing inaccuracies
Standard_of_Review: reasonableness for misrepresentation, correctness for procedural fairness
Document_Fraud: no explicit document fraud, but testimonial inconsistencies

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of procedural fairness and reasonableness of decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants were aware of their immigration history and prior cautions
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Past reports of unauthorized work, immigration history
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section requiring proof of intent to leave Canada at end of authorized stay
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Officer relied on undisclosed adverse information
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicants' knowledge of immigration history and previous warnings
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under s. 72(1) of the Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged failure to disclose adverse reports
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; Officer considered available evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness requires notice of adverse information
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of compliance mixed with past violations

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of work permit and visitor record refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and reasonableness in refusal based on unauthorized work
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Ronner had history of unauthorized work; Ms. Ronner allegedly assisted unpaid
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Reports of prior unauthorized work, business involvement
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Prohibition on working without authorization
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Officer used undisclosed reports to justify refusal
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Prior work violations and risk of non-compliance
Crimes.Application_Error: Lack of explicit disclosure of all adverse reports
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonable opportunity to respond to adverse information
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; context supported reasonable conclusions
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and statutory compliance
Crimes.Application_Factor: Long presence in Canada and family ties

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to leave Canada by end of authorized stay
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Requirement to depart at end of temporary status
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants sought extensions but had history of non-compliance
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Implied through continued stay despite risks
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Notice of adverse information
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Officer to assess compliance
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Immigration history, prior reports of unauthorized work
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubts about intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn of Officer’s decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness and reasonableness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk of continued non-compliance and past violations

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of extension refusal based on work violations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Use of undisclosed reports and procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Ronner aware of past concerns despite claims of unawareness
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Historical reports from 1990 and 1992 on unauthorized work
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Prohibition on foreign nationals working without permit
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Officer relied on undisclosed adverse information
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Pattern of non-compliance and credibility concerns
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to explicitly disclose all adverse reports
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Opportunity to respond to negative findings
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and statutory interpretation
Crimes.Application_Factor: Length of stay and integration in Canada

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer violated procedural fairness or based the decision on erroneous facts
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; original rejection upheld
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in financial documentation; inability to clarify business operations

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA section 72
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed visas and sought permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of H&C refusal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remission for reconsideration
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) considerations
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably assessed establishment but failed to properly analyze psychological hardship and conflated risk with hardship

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Erroneous assessment of hardship, establishment, and best interests of children
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA section 72
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Long presence in Canada and psychological challenges
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inadequate evaluation of psychological hardship
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to substantively evaluate key evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds
Crimes.Application_Factor: Unauthorized stay and integration

Crimes.Dispute_Type: H&C application refusal after re-entry post-removal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Improper focus on illegal stay and inadequate hardship analysis
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA section 72
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Return to Canada after removal; psychological hardship not addressed
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient consideration of psychological evidence
Crimes.Application_Error: Conflation of risk assessment with hardship analysis
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds
Crimes.Application_Factor: Illegal entry and prior removal

Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to abuse by her stepfather; argued home country could not protect her; did not file complaint with authorities after reaching adulthood
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence of independent judiciary enforcing laws against violence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide clear and convincing evidence of inadequate state protection; no complaint filed with authorities
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard as defined in Dunsmuir
Decision_Rationale: RPD presumed state capacity to protect; applicant failed to rebut presumption with clear and convincing evidence; credible documentary evidence supported functioning judiciary

Application_Facts: Applicant provided various identity documents post-hearing but failed to submit them timely.
RPD found documents lacked probative value and were not new evidence.
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent documentation and late submission of evidence undermined credibility.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review analyzed procedural fairness, credibility assessment, and 'no credible basis' finding.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide timely and credible identity documentation
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found no credible basis for the claim due to inconsistent and untimely documents.
Decision_Outcome: RPD did not err in rejecting documents.
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no credible basis confirmed.
Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to establish identity and provide credible evidence.

Legal_Issue: Whether RPD erred in rejecting applicant's identity documents and finding no credible basis.
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no credible basis upheld.
Credibility_Assessment: RPD questioned authenticity due to discrepancies in dates of birth and names.
Evidence_Ignored: Post-hearing documents considered irrelevant due to pre-existence
Application_Factor: Timeliness and authenticity of submitted documents
Decision_Outcome: RPD decision upheld as within reasonable range
Document_Fraud: Discrepancies in names and dates of birth across documents

Dispute_Type: Credibility and procedural fairness in refugee claim
Legal_Issue: Whether RPD breached procedural fairness or erred in credibility assessment and 'no credible basis' finding.
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no credible basis upheld.
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in dates of birth, names, and lack of timely documentation.
Evidence_Type: Multiple identity documents with conflicting information
Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection based on nationality and risk
Application_Error: Failure to produce timely and credible documentation
Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness; credibility findings upheld.
Document_Fraud: Inconsistent identity documents indicating potential misrepresentation

Application_Facts: Applicant faced poor translation during the hearing, impacting credibility assessment; significant discrepancies in interpretation affecting key details of his claim.
Procedural_Issue: Poor quality of translation affected the applicant's ability to present his case effectively
Evidence_Used: Evidence showing significant discrepancies in interpretation
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Translation errors undermining reliability of evidence and testimony
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility assessment was impacted due to inaccurate translation
Outcome: Decision overturned, case referred back for rehearing
Decision_Rationale: Procedural unfairness caused by translation issues
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) or equivalent decision-making body

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements in relation to citizenship application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Unreasonable assessment of evidence and misapplication of qualitative test for residency
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility undermined by incomplete disclosure and contradictory evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Residency requirement under Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False statements affecting residency qualification
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to address material absences and inconsistencies
Crimes.Application_Error: Incomplete disclosure of absences and financial activity
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Qualitative test for residency (centralization of life in Canada)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard in administrative decision-making
Crimes.Application_Factor: Residency compliance through physical presence or centralization
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable; case remitted to Minister for redetermination
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False or misleading information in citizenship application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation regarding residency for citizenship purposes
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Unreasonable assessment of evidence and misapplication of Koo’s qualitative test for residency
Crimes.Governing_Law: Citizenship Act, Koo v. Canada precedent
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubts due to undeclared trips and implausible explanations
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Residency requirement under section 5 of Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation of factual basis for residency
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to assess whether applicant centralized life in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable justification required for residency determination
Crimes.Application_Factor: Pattern of absences and financial ties abroad
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Error in credibility and legal test application; remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Inaccurate representation of residency in application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose material information in citizenship application
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 5(1) of the Citizenship Act – Residency requirement
Crimes.Governing_Law: Citizenship Act, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to report absences, provided inconsistent credit card explanations, possible undisclosed passports
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Questioned due to unreported absences and foreign activity
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of relevant travel and financial information
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Insufficient scrutiny by Citizenship Judge
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentation supporting claimed residency
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Serious doubts due to incomplete disclosures
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision; remitted to Minister for reassessment
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remittal to Minister for proper evaluation
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of administrative decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Speculative assumptions and inadequate analysis rendered decision unreasonable
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possibly using a minor to commit fraud (credit card misuse)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credit card misuse and potential fraud
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of accepting implausible explanation for unauthorized transactions
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Failure to investigate child’s capacity to make international purchases
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judge’s acceptance of explanation deemed unreasonable
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to justify unusual financial activity
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Explanations must be credible and consistent with known facts
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Potential fraud involving minor and misuse of financial instruments
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing and location of credit card transactions abroad
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRAC method applied in judicial review
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Attributed transactions to minor child without corroborating evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Case remitted to Minister for redetermination
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 122 of Criminal Code (fraud), Citizenship Act misrepresentation clauses

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment based on inconsistencies in testimony and documentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD reasonably questioned credibility due to omissions, inconsistent travel details, questionable military documents, and delayed asylum claims
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 97(1) of IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Persecution in Turkey due to Kurdish activism and draft evasion
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Cumulative inconsistencies undermining credibility
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of credibility assessment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing and plausibility of asylum claim
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspicious military documents lacking official features

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 30(1) of IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada illegally and claimed asylum after detentions in Turkey
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Credibility issues related to threats, travel, and documentation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of RPD decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over RPD decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroboration for key events
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found inconsistencies affecting reliability
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn of RPD decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of administrative decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Credibility undermined by multiple inconsistencies

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements to immigration officials
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Truthfulness of applicant’s statements in asylum application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Multiple inconsistencies in testimony and forms; minor errors but overall reasonable finding
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 40(1)(a) of IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to Kurdish activism and draft evasion
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Cumulative effect of inconsistencies
Application_Error: Inconsistent statements about travel and threats
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness in administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Plausibility and consistency of narrative

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility of draft evasion as basis for persecution claim
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Letters on draft evasion lacked security features and were deemed suspicious
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed due to lack of credibility
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish risk of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in testimony and questionable documents
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution due to draft evasion and Kurdish activism
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed due to credibility issues
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed fear of imprisonment and persecution in Turkey
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 96 and s. 40(1)(a)

Violation_Type: Refugee claim based on lack of well-founded fear of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Sri Lanka due to Tamil ethnicity; Board found no credible evidence linking fear to race or political opinion; incidents involved authorities and post-war extortion unrelated to Convention grounds
Procedural_Issue: Credibility assessment, linkage of evidence to Convention grounds
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, encounters with authorities, context of post-war Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence connecting experiences to race or political opinion
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant's fear not credible or insufficiently linked to protected grounds
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by the Refugee Protection Division
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the denial and granting of refugee protection
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under Section 96
Decision_Rationale: No evidence established a link between the applicant's experiences and persecution based on race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or social group; incidents were attributed to general law enforcement or criminal activity
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB), Federal Court

Legal_Provision_Violated: Rule 58(1), Rule 61, IRPA sections related to refugee claim procedures
Governing_Law: Baker v. Canada (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration)
Application_Facts: Jang family's PIF was submitted 7 days late; Board had valid contact information; contradictory notices issued by the Board
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide meaningful reasons for abandonment decision
Evidence_Used: Standard form indicating late PIF submission
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No explanation provided for abandonment despite available contact information
Insufficient justification for applying abandonment rule
Decision_Outcome: Claim declared abandoned by the Board
Outcome: Court set aside the Board's decision
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the abandonment decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of abandonment issue by a different panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement for meaningful reasons in decisions of significant impact
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to provide adequate reasoning; contact information negated automatic abandonment; important decisions require substantive justification

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 183 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant lived in Canada illegally for over 20 years, repeatedly attempted to regularize status, and applied for permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to provide adequate reasons for refusal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Length of stay, family ties, hardship upon removal
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not properly address relevant evidence of establishment in Canada
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not applicable
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of H&C application by a different immigration officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard under administrative law
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient reasoning provided by Officer despite evidence of long-term residence and hardship
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) Officer

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant sought permanent residency based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds after prolonged illegal stay in Canada.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to adequately analyze degree of establishment and hardship
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Duration of residence, family connections, social integration
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not meaningfully engage with evidence supporting establishment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review successful; case remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a new immigration officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Discretionary fairness and reasonableness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decision lacked sufficient explanation regarding lack of unusual hardship or establishment

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of refusal of H&C application
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 25(1)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; matter referred back for re-determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse finding on credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and testimonial evidence of long-term presence and community ties
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25(1) IRPA – Humanitarian and Compassionate considerations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Hardship upon removal, deep establishment in Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Degree of establishment and adequacy of reasoning in refusal
Crimes.Application_Error: Insufficient analysis and explanation in decision
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of 20+ years of residence, familial and social ties
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness review under administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Length of unauthorized stay, attempts to comply, family hardship
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of application to regularize status

Crimes.Violation_Type: Immigration violation due to remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25(1) of IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed her visa, established herself in Canada, sent money home, has children in Canada
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Temporary resident who became out of status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Exemption sought from requirement to apply for permanent residency from outside Canada
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; establishment found admirable
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application for humanitarian and compassionate grounds refused
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from outside application requirement based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Permanent residency in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of officer’s assessment under H&C provisions
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Establishment was admirable but result of voluntary actions; no disproportionate hardship; best interests of children considered but not outweighing immigration compliance

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Deportation and humanitarian relief under immigration law
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of officer’s refusal of humanitarian and compassionate grounds for permanent residence
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of applicant's establishment, family ties, and hardship upon removal
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unusual or undeserved hardship
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 25 allows exemption based on H&C grounds, including best interests of children
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Hardship if deported, family ties in Canada, best interests of children
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate provisions under IRPA
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Immigration Officer assessed factors and found no basis for exemption
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Permanent resident status on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25(1) of IRPA
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Officer and Federal Court (on review)

Application_Facts: Suspicion of association with a known criminal led to the suspension and subsequent revocation of the applicants' security clearances.
Procedural_Issue: Applicants were not given detailed reasons or access to the intelligence report before submitting their responses.
Key facts and opinions challenging their credibility were undisclosed.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient disclosure of information prevented meaningful participation.
Credibility_Assessment: The Minister relied on undisclosed opinions challenging the applicants' credibility.
Outcome: The matter is remitted for redetermination
Decision_Rationale: The duty of procedural fairness requires providing sufficient information to allow meaningful participation in decision-making, considering the nature of the decision, statutory scheme, and impact on rights. The Minister breached this duty by failing to disclose key information.

Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate Grounds Application Rejection
Application_Facts: Lack of substantive evidence regarding hardship or unique circumstances; consideration of children's interests in Canada and Nigeria
Evidence_Used: Assessment of hardship, establishment, and risk factors
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of substantive evidence on hardship or unique circumstances
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; decision upheld
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the children as a factor in H&C assessment
Decision_Rationale: No compelling reasons to grant an exception; children's interests considered but not outweighing other factors

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the respondents comply with environmental assessment laws, particularly the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act or EARP Guidelines Order?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Environmental Assessment Act, Chlorobiphenyls Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Initial assessments conducted under both EARP Guidelines Order and CEAA; March 1996 Assessment addressed factors required by CEAA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Respondents complied with applicable environmental laws
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show non-compliance or procedural error
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Expert analysis and prior assessments supported reasonableness of decision
Crimes.Legal_Rule: CEAA applies to projects post-January 19, 1995, unless initial assessment completed under EARP before enactment
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Potential PCB release during barge recovery
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: No significant procedural errors; decision reasonable
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Environmental assessments, risk of PCB release, comparative harm of leaving barge vs. recovery
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian Environmental Assessment Act, EARP Guidelines Order
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Recovery action prevents greater environmental harm
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Environmental impact assessments, expert testimony
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial intervention to halt barge recovery
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; project allowed to proceed
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section of Chlorobiphenyls Regulations regarding PCB handling
Crimes.Authority: Federal environmental regulatory bodies and reviewing court

Crimes.Violation_Type: Alleged deposit of deleterious substance under Fisheries Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Fisheries Act – prohibition on depositing deleterious substances in fish-frequented waters
Crimes.Application_Facts: Lifting the 'Irving Whale' barge containing PCBs may release small amounts into water
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether judicial review was appropriate and whether assessment process was lawful
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction over fisheries and environmental protection
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Estimates of PCB release during lifting, historical leak data, environmental monitoring
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of excessive or uncontrolled release beyond natural leakage
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Authorities’ risk assessment deemed credible and scientifically grounded
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No breach of Fisheries Act found
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Halt to barge recovery due to environmental concerns
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Injunction or declaration of non-compliance
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether action constitutes a 'deposit' under the Fisheries Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Action manages existing contamination and prevents greater future harm
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Department of Fisheries and Oceans, federal environmental assessors

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Compliance with environmental assessment procedures for barge recovery
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the respondents comply with applicable environmental assessment laws before proceeding?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Environmental Assessment Act (CEAA), EARP Guidelines Order
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of environmental assessment process
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: March 1996 Assessment concluded impacts were insignificant or mitigable
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Respondents complied with EARP Guidelines Order
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate failure to consider relevant factors
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Extensive analysis and expert advice supported conclusion
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Projects must undergo initial assessment to determine significance of environmental effects
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Concerns about PCB contamination and adequacy of assessment
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: No substantial error in applying EARP instead of CEAA
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Environmental assessment report, expert opinions, technology for mitigation
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Assessment was thorough and decision was precautionary
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Scientific studies, environmental modeling, technical reports
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial declaration of non-compliance and project stoppage
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; project allowed to proceed
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Provisions of CEAA and EARP Guidelines Order on initial environmental assessment
Crimes.Authority: Federal environmental assessment authority and reviewing court

Crime_Name: Administrative Error in Visa Application Rejection
Application_Facts: Applicants provided inconsistent stories and incomplete documentation; affidavit credibility questioned by visa officer; clarification requested but not provided
Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of duty of fairness
Credibility_Assessment: Affidavit credibility questioned due to inconsistencies
Outcome: Application to quash decision dismissed
Relief_Sought: Judicial review to quash visa officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Bad faith or legal error required for judicial interference
Decision_Rationale: No bad faith or legal error found; visa officer acted within discretionary authority under subsection 114(2); insufficient and inconsistent evidence undermined H&C claims

Legal_Provision_Violated: Definition of Convention refugee under the Immigration Act
Application_Facts: Applicant and her group possessed incriminating knowledge about a corrupt mayor, leading to threats and risk of persecution; knowledge deemed an unchangeable characteristic
Procedural_Issue: CRDD failed to properly analyze 'particular social group' and ignored political opinion as a basis for persecution
Evidence_Used: Credible claims of persecution based on possession of incriminating knowledge
Evidentiary_Deficiency: CRDD did not adequately consider evidence related to political opinion and social group membership
Credibility_Assessment: Claims found credible by reviewing court
Decision_Outcome: Denial of refugee status by CRDD
Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for re-adjudication
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review, re-determination by new tribunal
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on protected grounds: race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or membership in a particular social group
Decision_Rationale: CRDD erred in law by misinterpreting 'particular social group' and failing to assess political opinion; decision not in accordance with statutory requirements

Violation_Type: Lack of credible evidence of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 97 (Person in need of protection) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed fear of persecution in Zimbabwe due to perceived political opinions
Wife and child dependent on principal applicant's claim
Residency_Compliance: Traveled freely in Zimbabwe without state interference
Procedural_Issue: Reliance on principal applicant’s claim without independent evidence from family members
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No credible or corroborative evidence of persecution
Insufficient individual claims by spouse and child
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicants' fear of persecution not credible
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by Refugee Protection Division
Outcome: Application dismissed by Federal Court
Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds
Decision_Rationale: No objective basis for fear of persecution
Inconsistent behavior with claimed fear (e.g., travel)

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration Act - Convention refugee definition, credibility requirements
Application_Facts: Applicant, an Angolan citizen, claimed refugee status in Canada based on fear of persecution; fled without documents; provided testimony with minor inconsistencies in dates and demeanor interpreted as lack of passion
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claimant was seeking entry/residence through refugee protection process
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged inconsistencies in testimony and lack of documentation raised concerns, but no intentional misrepresentation found
Procedural_Issue: CRDD's credibility assessment relied on unreasonable grounds including cultural bias and lack of documentary evidence despite context of flight
Jurisdictional_Issue: Judicial review under subsection 82.1 of the Immigration Act
Evidence_Used: Oral testimony, lack of supporting documents, perceived emotional demeanor
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documents due to fleeing circumstances, minor date inconsistencies
Credibility_Assessment: CRDD doubted credibility based on lack of documents, inconsistent dates, and perceived lack of passion; court found these reasons patently unreasonable
Outcome: Judicial review granted; CRDD decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee, protection from removal
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a different panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds
Decision_Rationale: Credibility findings must be reasonable and based on substantial evidence; minor inconsistencies and lack of documents do not undermine claims when context is considered; cultural biases must not influence assessments
Authority_Responsible: Canadian Refugee Determination Division (CRDD), Federal Court on judicial review

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, SOR/2002-227
Crimes.Application_Facts: Nguyen, a Vietnamese citizen, had a nine-month absence from his Vietnamese business and expressed intent to stay in Canada with his children.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national applying for a work permit
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to prove compliance with temporary residency requirements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessed reasonableness of visa officer's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Applicant's ties to Vietnam, duration of absence from business, statements about family in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of strong evidence showing intent to return to Vietnam
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Nguyen's claim of intent to return was weakened by prolonged absence and desire to remain with children
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn refusal and grant work permit
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Proof of intention to leave Canada at the end of authorized stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Tribunal reasonably concluded Nguyen did not prove he would leave Canada after his authorized stay

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer acted reasonably in refusing the work permit due to insufficient proof of intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, Regulation 200(1)(b)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; work permit not issued
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Nguyen lacked strong ties to Vietnam and expressed desire to stay in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Business ownership in Vietnam, duration of absence, familial connections in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Regulation 200(1)(b) – Requirement to prove intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant failed to meet regulatory requirement to demonstrate intent to depart Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Weak ties to home country and expressed intent to remain in Canada
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient evidence of intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective assessment of applicant’s intent based on ties to home country
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Proof required under Regulation 200(1)(b)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Duration of absence from Vietnamese business and presence of children in Canada
Crimes.Authority: Canadian Visa Office, Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 40(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after the expiration of their authorized stay; pending applications and personal relationships cited as reasons to defer removal.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant with rejected permanent residence and risk assessment applications
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Motion for stay of removal filed after final removal order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over stay applications
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Pending immigration applications, family ties in Canada, claimed risks in Peru
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Claims were vague, speculative, and unsupported by evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Low credibility due to lack of substantiated evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on humanitarian and compelling circumstances
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Deferral of deportation
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious question, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No serious question, irreparable harm, or favorable balance of convenience demonstrated

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 48 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant sought to delay removal citing family separation, inadequate care for dependents, and fear of assailants in Peru.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national subject to a final removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review and stay application following administrative rejections
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's authority to grant stays under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family ties, health concerns, safety risks upon return
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Assertions not supported by concrete evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal based on special circumstances
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious question, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Public interest favors enforcement; no irreparable harm shown

Crimes.Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate application refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Eligibility for H&C consideration and stay of removal
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Post-refusal judicial review and stay application
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of family ties, integration, and risks in country of return
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application and stay motion both denied
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Legal_Rule: H&C considerations require compelling grounds beyond normal immigration rules
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Family separation, best interests of child, risk in Peru
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Pending applications, spousal relationship, perceived risks
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Sections 25(1) IRPA for H&C, Section 48 for removal
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Canada Border Services Agency upheld removal order
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, medical reports, police records (if any)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA Section 25(1)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Pre-removal risk assessment refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 48 and Section 107-113 of IRPA (PRRA provisions)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk of harm if returned to Peru; previous refugee claim and H&C applications rejected.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Inadmissible foreign national with prior negative determinations
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: PRRA conducted post-rejection; appeal via stay motion
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of PRRA outcome
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Alleged threats from assailants, lack of state protection, family vulnerability
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborating evidence; claims previously assessed and dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Low credibility due to inconsistency and lack of proof
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on risk claims
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment or deferral of removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious question, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No new evidence of risk; public interest supports removal
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA), Immigration Division

Legal_Provision_Violated: subparagraph 44(3)(b)(i) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Application_Facts: Guy Lafond filed a discrimination complaint with the CHRC, alleging harassment and differential treatment at work.
Procedural_Issue: CHRC dismissed the complaint after investigation and review of representations
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence for differential treatment due to age, sex, or disability
Outcome: Court dismissed the judicial review application, upholding the CHRC's decision
Decision_Rationale: The CHRC's decision was reasonable as it fell within acceptable outcomes based on facts and law; insufficient evidence found for discrimination claims

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's decision based on credibility and state protection availability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding due to contradictions and omissions in testimony and forms
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, written statements, Personal Information Forms (PIFs)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections related to misrepresentation and refugee eligibility under IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to threats in home country
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credibility and failure to test state protection in Mexico
Crimes.Application_Error: Omission of key information in application forms and inconsistencies in statements
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; Board considered all relevant evidence consistent with its mandate
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard for negative credibility findings and burden to demonstrate lack of state protection
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in accounts of persecution and failure to seek local protection
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected, judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No forgery, but material omissions and misrepresentations in official forms

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements to an immigration officer
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's decision based on applicant's credibility and state protection availability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility due to contradictions between entry statements and testimony
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Port of entry statements, hearing testimony, application documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Provisions prohibiting false statements in immigration proceedings
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by PRI members in Mexico
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistent identification of persecutors and lack of proof regarding state protection
Crimes.Application_Error: Contradictions at port of entry and omission of critical details
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; court found Board’s analysis sufficient and evidence properly weighed
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard for assessing credibility and rebutting presumption of state protection
Crimes.Application_Factor: False or inconsistent statements about identity of persecutors
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied, judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False oral/written statements at entry, not document forgery

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose material facts in Personal Information Form
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's decision based on lack of credibility and failure to rebut state protection presumption
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility undermined by contradictions and omissions in PIF and testimony
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal Information Form (PIF), oral testimony, supporting documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Requirements for full disclosure in immigration applications
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Threats from Mexican political party members
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Material omissions in PIF and failure to access state protection in Mexico
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose knowledge of fraud and inconsistencies in political timeline
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No indication of ignored evidence; Board relied on available credible information
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty to disclose material facts and burden to prove ineffective state protection
Crimes.Application_Factor: Non-disclosure of key facts in mandatory forms
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim dismissed, no relief granted on judicial review
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Material omissions in official immigration form (PIF)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of CRA's decision not to waive penalty and interest for late filing
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: CRA reviewed taxpayer's history of late filings and absence of special circumstances
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unreasonableness of CRA's decision
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Taxpayer's repeated late filings undermined claim for relief
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Penalty of $25 per day up to 100 days; Minister may waive under fairness provision if justified
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unfairness and lack of disclosed income justifying waiver
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: History of late filings, no undisclosed income, no special circumstances
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal tax administration and judicial review principles
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA denied waiver citing compliance history and lack of justification
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of filing history and tax forms
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; taxpayer ordered to pay $200 in costs
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 163.2 and related provisions of the Income Tax Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to file tax information on time
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and fairness of CRA's refusal to waive late-filing penalty
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessment based on taxpayer’s pattern of non-compliance and lack of exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On taxpayer to show decision was unreasonable or unfair
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Repeated late filings reduced credibility of hardship claims
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Penalty of $25 per day (up to 100 days); discretionary waiver under 'fairness' provision
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: No new income disclosed, penalty seen as unjust
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Filing history, nature of disclosure, absence of mitigating factors
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Income Tax Act and administrative fairness principles
Crimes.Defendant_Response: CRA maintained denial of relief due to lack of justification
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Tax records, correspondence, compliance history
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 163.2 of the Income Tax Act

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of RPD's rejection of Tazkira and refusal to grant adjournment
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside, case remitted
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD questioned credibility based on signatures, stamps, and procurement methods
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections related to refugee eligibility and procedural fairness under IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection due to domestic abuse
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Document authenticity and need for adjournment
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Refugee hearing before the Refugee Protection Division (RPD)
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider risks of deportation and contradictory evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Contradictory evidence regarding Tazkira authenticity and risks upon return
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and reasonableness of credibility findings
Crimes.Application_Factor: Need for corroborating documentation and risk of harm
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged irregularities in Tazkira (signatures, stamps, procurement)

Crimes.Victim_Status: Survivor of domestic abuse seeking refugee protection
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Threats linked to control and retaliation for perceived disloyalty
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Not assessed due to lack of formal reporting
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – credible threat of lethal violence
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of harm if returned to Afghanistan
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Personalized and ongoing threat from spouse
Crimes.Threat_Source: Husband threatening death if applicant 'conspired' against him
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on marital relationship and gender
Crimes.Targeted_Individual: Applicant as a female resisting spousal authority
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: RPD doubted credibility; court found dismissal unreasonable
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD failed to properly analyze gravity of threats
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: N/A – matter of refugee determination, not criminal sentencing
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA section 96 – Convention refugee definition

Crimes.Victim_Status: Survivor of domestic and sexual violence
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Abuse occurring in context of forced marriage and power imbalance
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Severe – ongoing sexual violence in domestic setting
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of re-victimization upon return
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systemic lack of state protection for women facing marital rape
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on gender and marital status
Crimes.Targeted_Individual: Female survivor of spousal sexual abuse
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Reliant on personal testimony due to lack of formal reporting
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient analysis by RPD despite plausible account
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: N/A – immigration context, not criminal prosecution
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA section 96 – well-founded fear of persecution

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Physical, emotional, and psychological abuse by spouse
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Isolation, lack of support, cultural barriers to escape
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: No known prior record of perpetrator
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – chronic abuse with physical and psychological harm
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Significant risk upon return due to absence of state protection
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Pattern of control and violence within family unit
Crimes.Threat_Source: Spousal abuse in context of patriarchal societal norms
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on gender and familial role
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: RPD raised doubts without adequate reasoning
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inadequate evaluation of consistency and plausibility
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 96 – Convention refugee due to state inability to protect

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repeated incidents, use of force, lack of recourse
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Elevated risk of further harm if returned
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Personalized threat from abuser with history of violence
Crimes.Threat_Source: Husband using physical force to maintain control
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – targeted due to marital relationship and gender
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Based on self-report and circumstantial indicators
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Unreasonable rejection of plausible claims
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 96 – fear of persecution based on membership in particular social group

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Forced confinement or abduction by spouse or family
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of coercion, isolation, threat of further harm
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Serious risk of recurrence upon return
Crimes.Threat_Source: Family or spouse enforcing traditional control
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on resistance to familial expectations
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: RPD did not adequately assess credibility
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Findings deemed unreasonable by Federal Court
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 96 – refugee protection due to state failure to prevent private acts of violence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving indirect involvement in drug trafficking
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA sections on criminality and inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to allow time to rebut allegations or provide evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Applicant sought time to obtain corroborative evidence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD decision set aside, remitted to new panel
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged involvement via spouse’s drug trafficking activities
Crimes.Mode_of_Entry: Claimant entered Canada as asylum seeker
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: No direct involvement alleged; association through husband
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Potential implication under organized crime provisions
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Fear of persecution due to association with criminal activity (forced participation or retaliation)
Crimes.Outcome: Remittal for reconsideration due to procedural unfairness
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Unreasonable assessment of identity and credibility, denial of fair process
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, particularly provisions on refugee protection and criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Refusal to grant adjournment despite legitimate need for evidence

Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Passport Order authorizes an Adjudicator to withhold passport services as a standalone sanction
Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside, matter remitted for redetermination
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate jurisdictional error
Legal_Rule: The Canadian Passport Order does not explicitly authorize standalone withholding of passport services
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review context)
Defendant_Response: Adjudicator ordered three-year withholding of services
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of decision
Outcome: Granted – decision quashed and remitted
Legal_Provision: Canadian Passport Order, sections related to refusal, revocation, and suspension

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s. 36(1)(a)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Correia was convicted of importing cocaine, leading to inadmissibility as a permanent resident.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Referral to admissibility hearing without consideration of humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Referred to Immigration Division for admissibility hearing
Crimes.Outcome: Removal order issued; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Inadmissibility based on conviction and sentence under IRPA s. 44(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations are not part of the referral process for serious criminality under IRPA

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: No requirement to consider humanitarian and compassionate factors at referral stage
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Conviction and sentence disclosed and relied upon
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Designated inadmissible due to serious criminality
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer, Minister’s Delegate, Immigration Division
Crimes.Outcome: Removal order upheld; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Conviction and sentence meet threshold for serious criminality

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Lawfulness of the Minister's decision to deny protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Assessed based on associations and activities
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA ss. 79(2), s. 80
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk of torture upon return to Egypt
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Danger to national security outweighs risk of torture
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and balancing of risks
Crimes.Application_Factor: Security threat due to alleged ties with Al-Jihad

Crimes.Crime_Name: Being a Member of a Terrorist Group
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Membership or association with terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Based on past activities and connections to Al-Jihad
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Supportive or affiliative conduct with terrorist group
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Alleged involvement based on circumstantial evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Evaluated through intelligence and behavioral patterns
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Reliability of intelligence linking individual to group
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Deemed credible by delegate
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 34(1)(b)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of protection refusal based on security grounds
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Denial of protection and potential deportation under security certificate

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Engagement in activities threatening national security
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Perceived threat due to links with extremist organizations
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Evaluation of potential harm to public safety or state interests
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Alleged support or facilitation of terrorism
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Inferred from indirect evidence and associations
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No indication of leadership – focus on affiliation
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Use of classified information in assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Accepted as sufficient by reviewing authority
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 34(1)(a)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Challenge to lawfulness of security-based inadmissibility
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Detention, deportation risk, ongoing legal proceedings

Crimes.National_Security_Danger: High risk posed to Canadian security
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Based on direct and indirect evidence of engagement
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Planning, supporting, or facilitating terrorist acts
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Inferred from circumstantial and intelligence evidence
Crimes.Leadership_Role: Not established – assessed as participant or supporter
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Balancing use of secret evidence with procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found consistent and plausible
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 34(1)(d)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of protection denial over national security concerns
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Refusal of protection, eligibility for security certificate process

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether costs can be awarded in a judicial review involving immigration misrepresentation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Rule 22 of the Federal Courts Rules
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed without costs
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Ibrahim's misrepresentations prolonged processing, but did not influence court decision
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Record of delays, security clearance resolution, application history
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Rule 22 – Prohibition on awarding costs absent special reasons
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged misrepresentation in permanent residence application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No special reasons such as unfair, oppressive, or improper conduct by either party
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No evidence that misrepresentations affected judicial proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Unfair, oppressive, or bad faith conduct required for cost award
Crimes.Application_Factor: Both parties contributed to delay
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No costs awarded to either party

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Costs dispute following moot judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether special reasons exist to award costs under Rule 22
Crimes.Governing_Law: Rule 22 of the Federal Courts Rules
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; no costs awarded
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Misrepresentations occurred but no bad faith shown
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Processing timelines, security clearance records, application materials
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Rule 22 – Costs only on special reasons
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Delays due to misrepresentation and administrative inaction
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Mutual contribution to delay; absence of improper conduct
Crimes.Application_Error: Inaccurate information provided in residency application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Presence of unfair, oppressive, or bad faith behavior
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No indication that false statements impacted fairness of process
Crimes.Legal_Standard: High threshold for cost awards under Rule 22
Crimes.Application_Factor: Combined effect of applicant misrepresentation and ministerial delay
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Submission of misleading information in immigration documents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on alleged membership in a terrorist organization
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s. 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Pusat suspected of membership in the PKK, an organization designated as terrorist; officer relied on undisclosed CBSA documents.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application for permanent residency under review
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to disclose inadmissibility grounds and deny opportunity to respond
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure of evidence to applicant
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Found inadmissible due to suspected PKK membership
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a different immigration officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Breach of procedural fairness in failing to disclose grounds and evidence

Crimes.Violation_Type: Denial of procedural fairness in immigration decision-making
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Common law and IRPA principles of procedural fairness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), common law
Crimes.Application_Facts: Pusat not informed of specific suspicions regarding PKK membership before or after interview; no chance to respond to allegations
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No pre-interview disclosure or post-interview response opportunity
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide applicant access to evidence against him
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Negative admissibility decision based on undisclosed information
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remittal for redetermination by new officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness: right to be informed and respond
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to uphold duty of fairness by withholding concerns and evidence

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged affiliation with PKK, a designated terrorist entity
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Suspected active or passive support of PKK activities
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership or association with proscribed group
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Alleged involvement with PKK, an armed separatist group engaged in terrorism
Crimes.Target_Entity: Government of Turkey and civilian populations (as per PKK's activities)
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Based on undisclosed CBSA intelligence; credibility not independently assessed at hearing
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Undisclosed documents used without applicant’s ability to rebut
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Intelligence reports, organizational links
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not fully evaluated due to procedural flaws
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged membership in terrorist organization affecting admissibility
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility and potential deportation if proven

Legal_Issue: Subjective fear of persecution in refugee claim
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; refugee claim denied
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's explanations for delay deemed unpersuasive; legal background and consultation with lawyer undermined credibility
Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, legal consultation records, applicant's conduct
Legal_Provision: Section 96 and Section 97 of IRPA regarding refugee protection
Key_Factor_in_Determination: 14-month delay in filing claim and lack of credible justification
Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Application_Error: Failure to file claim without delay and provide satisfactory explanation for delay
Legal_Standard: Subjective fear of persecution must be genuine
Application_Factor: Delay in filing, applicant’s conduct and background

Crimes.Crime_Name: Marriage Fraud under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Genuineness of marriage for immigration purposes
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, Section 4
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Ms. Ramirez did not testify, raising credibility concerns
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 4 - Marriage not genuine if entered primarily for immigration purposes
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Marriage entered into primarily for immigration purposes
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of cohabitation and unresolved credibility issues
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Marriage must be genuine and not primarily for immigration benefit
Crimes.Application_Factor: Intent and credibility of the parties

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Genuineness of marriage based on all evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, Section 4
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Ms. Ramirez did not testify, raising credibility concerns
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 4 - Foreign national not a spouse if marriage not genuine and primarily for immigration purposes
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation regarding marital genuineness
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Unresolved credibility issues despite supporting evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Marriage must be genuine and not primarily for immigration benefit
Crimes.Application_Factor: Intent and credibility of the parties

Crimes.Crime_Name: Knowingly concealing material circumstances in citizenship application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the defendant obtain Canadian citizenship by false representation, fraud, or knowingly concealing material circumstances?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Defendant understood warnings despite limited English; belief that charges were minor not accepted as justification
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonies from citizenship officials, defendant's application records, interview notes
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Citizenship Act - revocation for false representation, fraud, or concealment of material circumstances
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to disclose criminal charges during citizenship process
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Materiality of undisclosed indictable criminal charges
Crimes.Application_Error: Non-disclosure of criminal charges despite multiple opportunities
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Significance of information to citizenship decision-making
Crimes.Legal_Standard: False representation, fraud, or knowingly concealing material circumstances under Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Factor: Defendant's awareness of questions and warnings during application
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Citizenship declared obtained by false means; revocation ordered
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Immigration referred case to Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the defendant obtain Canadian citizenship by false representation, fraud, or knowingly concealing material circumstances?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Testimonies from citizenship officials and defendant considered
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Minister to prove false representation or concealment
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Defendant understood process despite limited English
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Citizenship may be revoked under Citizenship Act for false representation or concealment
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Concealment of criminal charges during citizenship application
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Belief that charges were minor and would be dropped
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Oral testimony, documentary evidence from application process
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Citizenship Act – revocation provisions
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court under referral from Minister

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of a narcotic for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Violation_Type: Concealment of material criminal history in citizenship application
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Citizenship Act – false representation or concealment of material circumstances
Crimes.Application_Facts: Defendant failed to disclose indictable drug charges during citizenship interviews and oath
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Failure to disclose serious criminal charges
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Referral to Federal Court after notice of intent to revoke
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Testimonies from citizenship officials, application documents
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Defendant understood questions despite language limitations
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Deprivation of citizenship status
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Materiality of concealed information under Citizenship Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Undisclosed indictable charges are material; belief in dismissal does not excuse disclosure duty
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Federal Court, upon referral by Minister of Immigration

Crimes.Violation_Type: Concealment of material criminal history in citizenship application
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Citizenship Act – false representation or concealment of material circumstances
Crimes.Application_Facts: Defendant failed to disclose criminal charges related to narcotics despite warnings
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Case referred to Federal Court after notice of intent to revoke
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Testimonies from officials, citizenship application records
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Defendant aware of questions and obligations despite belief charges were minor
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Cancellation of citizenship status
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Materiality of undisclosed criminal charges under Citizenship Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Charges were material; failure to disclose constitutes concealment regardless of personal belief
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Federal Court, on referral from Minister

Crimes.Crime_Name: Acts of violence endangering lives or safety of persons in Canada
Crimes.Violation_Type: Detention and release under immigration law
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration Act s. 40.1
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant not removed within 120 days and sought release from detention
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Motion for recusal based on alleged judicial bias
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Same judge handling inadmissibility and release hearing
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Judge previously found applicant credible as a security risk
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Recusal of judge due to perceived bias
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable apprehension of bias test
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Objective standard: whether an informed person would perceive bias
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judges can remain impartial despite prior findings; duty to apply law fairly
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Designated judge under Immigration Act s. 40.1

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Involvement in terrorist organization poses threat to national security
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Risk to public safety and national security
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Applicant deemed credible security risk based on certificate
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Prior determination of membership in terrorist organization
Crimes.Organization_Involved: Not specified in text, but implied by certificate
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Evidence accepted in camera; credibility upheld by prior ruling
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Use of in camera evidence without full disclosure to applicant
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Classified intelligence and in camera submissions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Judge assessed applicant as credible threat in prior proceeding
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Consistency with intelligence and prior judicial findings
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Reasonable grounds to believe involvement (balance of probabilities)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration Act s. 40.1
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial impartiality in subsequent release hearing
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Continued detention pending removal; limited right to appeal

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Active participation in terrorism threatening public safety
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Direct threat to Canadian society and institutions
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Certificate found reasonable by designated judge
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Prior finding of engagement in terrorism
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Acts constituting terrorism as defined under law
Crimes.Target_Entity: General public and national security interests
Crimes.Organization_Involved: Not explicitly named, inferred from security context
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Subject of security certificate alleging engagement in terrorism
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Relied on classified evidence reviewed in camera
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of full disclosure to applicant; reliance on secret evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Intelligence reports, in camera submissions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Judge previously accepted credibility of allegations
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Reasonable grounds to believe engagement in terrorism
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration Act s. 40.1
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Fairness of same judge hearing release application
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Ongoing detention; motion for recusal denied

Legal_Issue: Does the exclusion of a homosexual partner from the Private Family Visiting Program violate the applicant's rights under Section 15 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms?
Governing_Law: Section 15 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Decision_Outcome: The exclusion violates Section 15 of the Charter; the decision was quashed and reconsideration ordered
Legal_Rule: Section 15 of the Charter prohibits discrimination based on enumerated or analogous grounds; sexual orientation is an analogous ground
Grounds_for_Claim: Discrimination based on sexual orientation in access to a prison visiting program
Outcome_on_Merits: The claim was successful; the exclusion was found discriminatory
Key_Evidence_Considered: Policy restricting visits to heterosexual common-law partners
Applicant's status as a homosexual inmate denied visitation rights
Legal_Framework: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, human rights legislation
Defendant_Response: Applied policy excluding same-sex partners from the visiting program
Remedy_Requested: Reconsideration of the grievance in compliance with Section 15
Outcome: Court quashed the decision and ordered reconsideration
Legal_Provision: Section 15(1) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms

Dispute_Type: Removal without access to Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA)
Legal_Issue: Whether the removal of Toth without access to a PRRA violates his Charter rights or Canada's international obligations
Governing_Law: Section 112(2)(b.1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Procedural_Stage: Motion for stay of removal in the Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: No new risk was established; alternative mechanisms existed to assess risk
Decision_Outcome: Motion dismissed; removal allowed to proceed
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to prove irreparable harm or unconstitutionality
Legal_Rule: Section 112(2)(b.1) IRPA prohibits PRRA applications within 12 months of a negative refugee determination
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of Charter rights and international obligations due to denial of PRRA
Key_Evidence_Considered: Toth's refugee claim rejection, country conditions in Hungary, status as Hungarian Roma
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, international obligations
Defendant_Response: Alternative mechanisms available to assess risk; no new evidence of danger
Evidence_Type: Legal arguments, statutory interpretation, human rights considerations
Outcome: Motion dismissed

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the marriage was genuine or primarily for acquiring status

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Financial dependence and lack of effort to support self in home country
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard of review
